item.title: Identifying package a file belongs to
item.description:
Different ways of identifying the package a file belongs to:

  • dpkg:
    1. quick
    2. works only for installed packages
    3. does not seem to work on symlinks :(
$ ls -l /usr/bin/vim /usr/bin/lsof
-rwxr-xr-x 1 root root 163224 Dec  2  2012 /usr/bin/lsof
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root     21 Apr  5 13:19 /usr/bin/vim -> /etc/alternatives/vim

$ dpkg -S /usr/bin/vim
dpkg-query: no path found matching pattern /usr/bin/vim

$ dpkg -S /usr/bin/lsof
lsof: /usr/bin/lsof
  • dlocate:
    1. quick, works only on installed packages
    2. needs to be installed separately: apt-get install dlocate
    3. works on symlinks too
    4. need to refresh dlocate db (sudo update-dlocatedb) after installing a new package :(
$ dlocate /usr/bin/vim
vim-runtime: /usr/bin/vimtutor
vim: /usr/bin/vim.basic
vim-tiny: /usr/bin/vim.tiny

$ sudo aptitude install apt-file
$ which apt-file
/usr/bin/apt-file
$ dlocate /usr/bin/apt-file     # fails; "sudo update-dlocatedb" needed
$ dpkg -S /usr/bin/apt-file
apt-file: /usr/bin/apt-file
  • apt-file:
    1. separate install
    2. quick for files in installed packages
    3. for packages not installed, prepare apt-file database: apt-file update
$ apt-file update
...
$ cd ~/.cache
$ du -sh apt-file
36M	apt-file

$ ls -l /usr/bin/thunderbird
ls: cannot access /usr/bin/thunderbird: No such file or directory

$ dlocate /usr/bin/thunderbird 

$ apt-file find /usr/bin/thunderbird 
thunderbird: /usr/bin/thunderbird

item.title: Avoiding recommended and suggested packages (Debian, Ubuntu)
item.description:
To avoid extra packages (i.e. recommended and suggested) being installed, add a file like say /etc/apt/apt.conf.d/01norecommend with this in it:

APT::Install-Recommends "0";
APT::Install-Suggests "0";
